column2: Activities that focus on the removal, recycling, or structural improvement of pavement layers

column6: Removal of the top layer of pavement to eliminate surface irregularities or prepare for overlay.
FDR (Full Depth Reclamation): Pulverizes the entire pavement layer and mixes it with stabilizing agents to create a strong base.
HIR (Hot In-Place Recycling): Heats and recycles the asphalt pavement on-site with rejuvenators to restore properties.
CIR (Cold In-Place Recycling): Recycles asphalt pavement without heat by milling and stabilizing it with emulsions.
CAM (Cement Asphalt Mixture): Combines cement and asphalt with existing materials to stabilize and strengthen pavement.
Spot Repairs: Localized fixes (e.g., potholes, structural repairs) to address severe damage in small areas.

column2: Techniques involving surface sealing and protection, typically without adding structural layers.
column19: Cape Seal - Chip Seal plus Micro-surfacing

column6: Application of asphalt binder followed by a layer of aggregate to seal and protect the surface.
Similar to Chip Seal, but includes a brooming process to work the binder into cracks for better sealing.
A thin layer of asphalt emulsion, aggregate, and additives applied to improve surface texture and longevity.
A combination of Chip Seal followed by Microsurfacing to enhance durability and aesthetics.
A thin spray of diluted asphalt emulsion applied to rejuvenate and protect aging asphalt.

column2: Processes that involve adding new structural or surface layers using asphalt mixes.

column6: Dense-graded asphalt mix designed for overlays to improve durability and surface performance.
Thin-lift asphalt overlay that provides a smooth, long-lasting surface.
Coarse-graded asphalt used for intermediate or surface layers in overlays.
column19: Cape Seal - Scrub Seal plus Micro-surfacing

column6: (Open-Graded Friction Course): Porous asphalt layer designed to improve skid resistance and reduce water spray.
